message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamic Evolution of Complex Networks: A Reinforcement Learning Approach Applying Evolutionary Games to Community Structure
Paper Abstract: Complex networks serve as abstract models for understanding real-world complex systems and provide frameworks for studying structured dynamical systems. This article addresses limitations in current studies on the exploration of individual birth-death and the development of community structures within dynamic systems. To bridge this gap, we propose a networked evolution model that includes the birth and death of individuals, incorporating reinforcement learning through games among individuals. Each individual has a lifespan following an arbitrary distribution, engages in games with network neighbors, selects actions using Q-learning in reinforcement learning, and moves within a two-dimensional space. The developed theories are validated through extensive experiments. Besides, we observe the evolution of cooperative behaviors and community structures in systems both with and without the birth-death process. The fitting of real-world populations and networks demonstrates the practicality of our model. Furthermore, comprehensive analyses of the model reveal that exploitation rates and payoff parameters determine the emergence of communities, learning rates affect the speed of community formation, discount factors influence stability, and two-dimensional space dimensions dictate community size. Our model offers a novel perspective on real-world community development and provides a valuable framework for studying population dynamics behaviors.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Birth–death process","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birth–death_process"},{"title":"Quasi-birth–death process","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasi-birth–death_process"},{"title":"Moran process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moran_process"},{"title":"Template:Death date and age - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Death-date_and_age"}]

Here are the search results for **Birth-death process**:

## Definition and Overview

The birth–death process is a special case of continuous-time Markov process where the state transitions are of only two types: "births", which increase the state variable by one and "deaths", which decrease the state by one.(no content)It was introduced by William Feller.

## How It Works

When a birth occurs, the process goes from state n to n + 1. When a death occurs, the process goes from state n to state n − 1.

## Applications

The model's name comes from a common application, the use of such models to represent the current size of a population where the transitions are literal births and deaths. Birth–death processes have many applications in demography, queueing theory, performance engineering, epidemiology, biology and other areas.(no content)They may be used, for example, to study the evolution of bacteria, the number of people with a disease within a population, or the number of customers in line at the supermarket.

## Related Concepts

The quasi-birth–death process describes a generalisation of the birth–death process. As with the birth-death process it moves up and down between levels one at a time, but the time between these transitions can have a more complicated distribution encoded in the blocks.

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Self-play (reinforcement learning technique) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-play_(reinforcement_learning_technique)"},{"title":"Model-free (reinforcement learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-free_(reinforcement_learning)"},{"title":"Category:Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Self-supervised learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-supervised_learning"},{"title":"Imitation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imitation_learning"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of Reinforcement Learning based on the search results:

## What is Reinforcement Learning?

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## Key Characteristics

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.

A fundamental concept in RL is the exploration-exploitation trade-off. To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## How It Works

Executing an action in a specific state provides the agent with a reward (a numerical score). The goal of the agent is to maximize its total reward.(no content)The environment is typically stated in the form of a Markov decision process, as many reinforcement learning algorithms use dynamic programming techniques.

## Applications and Impact

It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.(no content)Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

Web search results for query: "Complex networks"

Links: [{"title":"Complex network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_network"},{"title":"Complex Networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_Networks"},{"title":"Climate as complex networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_as_complex_networks"},{"title":"Robustness of complex networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robustness_of_complex_networks"},{"title":"Network theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_theory"},{"title":"Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science"},{"title":"Supply chain network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain_network"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Macroprogramming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macroprogramming"},{"title":"Manlio De Domenico - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manlio_De_Domenico"}]

Here are the search results for "Complex networks":

## Definition and Overview

In the context of network theory, a complex network is a graph (network) with non-trivial topological features—features that do not occur in simple networks such as lattices or random graphs but often occur in networks representing real systems.

## Key Characteristics

Most social, biological, and technological networks display substantial non-trivial topological features, with patterns of connection between their elements that are neither purely regular nor purely random. Such features include a heavy tail in the degree distribution, a high clustering coefficient, assortativity or disassortativity among vertices, community structure, and hierarchical structure.

## Research Field

The study of complex networks is a young and active area of scientific research (since 2000) inspired largely by empirical findings of real-world networks such as computer networks, biological networks, technological networks, brain networks, climate networks and social networks.

## Important Network Classes

Two well-known and much studied classes of complex networks are scale-free networks and small-world networks, whose discovery and definition are canonical case-studies in the field. Both are characterized by specific structural features—power-law degree distributions for the former and short path lengths and high clustering for the latter.

## Interdisciplinary Applications

The field continues to develop at a brisk pace, and has brought together researchers from many areas including mathematics, physics, electric power systems, biology, climate, computer science, sociology, epidemiology, and others.

I've found comprehensive information about population dynamics. Here's an overview of the key results:

## What is Population Dynamics?

Population dynamics is the type of mathematics used to model and study the size and age composition of populations as dynamical systems.(no content)Population dynamics is a branch of mathematical biology, and uses mathematical techniques such as differential equations to model behaviour.

## Key Variables and Processes

Simplified population models usually start with four key variables (four demographic processes) including death, birth, immigration, and emigration.

## Historical Foundation

It is widely regarded in the field of population ecology as the first principle of population dynamics, with Malthus as the founder.(no content)One of the most basic and milestone models of population growth was the logistic model of population growth formulated by Pierre François Verhulst in 1838.(no content)The logistic model takes the shape of a sigmoid curve and describes the growth of a population as exponential, followed by a decrease in growth, and bound by a carrying capacity due to environmental pressures.

## Applications

Population models are used to determine maximum harvest for agriculturists, to understand the dynamics of biological invasions, and for environmental conservation. Population models are also used to understand the spread of parasites, viruses, and disease.

The search results also cover specialized applications in fisheries, pest control, metapopulations, and source-sink dynamics, among other topics related to population dynamics.

I've found comprehensive information about population dynamics. Here's an overview of the key results:

## What is Population Dynamics?

Population dynamics is the type of mathematics used to model and study the size and age composition of populations as dynamical systems.(no content)Population dynamics is a branch of mathematical biology, and uses mathematical techniques such as differential equations to model behaviour.

## Key Variables and Processes

Simplified population models usually start with four key variables (four demographic processes) including death, birth, immigration, and emigration.

## Historical Foundation

It is widely regarded in the field of population ecology as the first principle of population dynamics, with Malthus as the founder.(no content)One of the most basic and milestone models of population growth was the logistic model of population growth formulated by Pierre François Verhulst in 1838.(no content)The logistic model takes the shape of a sigmoid curve and describes the growth of a population as exponential, followed by a decrease in growth, and bound by a carrying capacity due to environmental pressures.

## Applications

Population models are used to determine maximum harvest for agriculturists, to understand the dynamics of biological invasions, and for environmental conservation. Population models are also used to understand the spread of parasites, viruses, and disease.

The search results also cover specialized applications in fisheries, pest control, metapopulations, and source-sink dynamics, among other topics related to population dynamics.

Web search results for query: "Evolutionary game theory"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Talk:Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Evolutionarily stable strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionarily_stable_strategy"},{"title":"Evolution and the Theory of Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_and_the_Theory_of_Games"},{"title":"Evolutionary economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_economics"},{"title":"Evolutionary graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_graph_theory"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_theory"}]

## Evolutionary Game Theory

Evolutionary game theory (EGT) is the application of game theory to evolving populations in biology.(no content)It defines a framework of contests, strategies, and analytics into which Darwinian competition can be modelled.

### Origins and Development

It originated in 1973 with John Maynard Smith and George R. Price's formalisation of contests, analysed as strategies, and the mathematical criteria that can be used to predict the results of competing strategies.(no content)Evolutionary game theory started with the problem of how to explain ritualized animal behaviour in a conflict situation.

### Key Differences from Classical Game Theory

Evolutionary game theory differs from classical game theory in focusing more on the dynamics of strategy change, which is influenced by the frequency of the competing strategies in the population.(no content)Maynard Smith realised that an evolutionary version of game theory does not require players to act rationally—only that they have a strategy, and the results of a game show how good that strategy was, just as evolution tests alternative strategies for the ability to survive and reproduce.

### How It Works

In biology, strategies are genetically inherited traits that control an individual's action, and the success of a strategy is determined by how good the strategy is in the presence of competing strategies and of the frequency with which those strategies are used.(no content)Rules include replicator dynamics, in other words how the fitter players will spawn more replicas of themselves into the population and how the less fit will be culled.

### Applications and Significance

Evolutionary game theory has contributed to the understanding of group selection, sexual selection, altruism, parental care, co-evolution, and ecological dynamics.(no content)It has become of interest to economists, sociologists, anthropologists, and philosophers.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Q-learning"

Links: [{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goal-conditioned_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Liz Crokin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liz_Crokin"},{"title":"List of public elementary schools in New York City - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_public_elementary_schools_in_New_York_City"},{"title":"Maggie Q - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maggie_Q"}]

## Q-learning Overview

Q-learning is a reinforcement learning algorithm that trains an agent to assign values to its possible actions based on its current state, without requiring a model of the environment (model-free).(no content)It can handle problems with stochastic transitions and rewards without requiring adaptations.

## Basic Approach

Q-learning at its simplest stores data in tables, but this approach falters with increasing numbers of states/actions since the likelihood of the agent visiting a particular state and performing a particular action is increasingly small.(no content)Q-learning can be combined with function approximation to make it possible to apply the algorithm to larger problems, even when the state space is continuous.

## History

Q-learning was introduced by Chris Watkins in 1989, with a convergence proof presented by Watkins and Peter Dayan in 1992.

## Deep Q-Learning

In 2014, Google DeepMind patented an application of Q-learning to deep learning, entitled "deep reinforcement learning" or "deep Q-learning," that can play Atari 2600 games at expert human levels.

## Off-Policy Learning

Value-function based methods such as Q-learning are better suited for off-policy learning and have better sample-efficiency—the amount of data required to learn a task is reduced because data is re-used for learning.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Community structure networks"

Links: [{"title":"Community structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_structure"},{"title":"Modularity (networks) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modularity_(networks)"},{"title":"Wireless community network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_community_network"},{"title":"Community network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_network"},{"title":"Complex network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_network"},{"title":"Configuration model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Configuration_model"},{"title":"Hierarchical clustering of networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_clustering_of_networks"},{"title":"Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science"},{"title":"Community (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_(ecology)"},{"title":"Louvain method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louvain_modularity"}]

Here are the search results for "Community structure networks":

## Overview

In the study of complex networks, a network is said to have community structure if the nodes of the network can be easily grouped into (potentially overlapping) sets of nodes such that each set of nodes is densely connected internally.

## Key Characteristics

In the particular case of non-overlapping community finding, the network divides naturally into groups of nodes with dense connections internally and sparser connections between groups.(no content)The more general definition is based on the principle that pairs of nodes are more likely to be connected if they are both members of the same community(ies), and less likely to be connected if they do not share communities.

## Significance

Finding an underlying community structure in a network, if it exists, is important for a number of reasons. Communities allow us to create a large scale map of a network since individual communities act like meta-nodes in the network which makes its study easier. Individual communities also shed light on the function of the system represented by the network since communities often correspond to functional units of the system.

## Community Detection Methods

Hierarchical clustering is one method for finding community structures in a network. The technique arranges the network into a hierarchy of groups according to a specified weight function. Additionally, in the Louvain Method of community detection, first small communities are found by optimizing modularity locally on all nodes, then each small community is grouped into one node and the first step is repeated.

Hierarchical clustering is one method for finding community structures in a network. The technique arranges the network into a hierarchy of groups according to a specified weight function. Additionally, in the Louvain Method of community detection, first small communities are found by optimizing modularity locally on all nodes, then each small community is grouped into one node and the first step is repeated.

## Overview

In the study of complex networks, a network is said to have community structure if the nodes of the network can be easily grouped into (potentially overlapping) sets of nodes such that each set of nodes is densely connected internally.

## Key Characteristics

In the particular case of non-overlapping community finding, the network divides naturally into groups of nodes with dense connections internally and sparser connections between groups.(no content)The more general definition is based on the principle that pairs of nodes are more likely to be connected if they are both members of the same community(ies), and less likely to be connected if they do not share communities.

## Significance

Finding an underlying community structure in a network, if it exists, is important for a number of reasons. Communities allow us to create a large scale map of a network since individual communities act like meta-nodes in the network which makes its study easier. Individual communities also shed light on the function of the system represented by the network since communities often correspond to functional units of the system.

## Community Detection Methods

Hierarchical clustering is one method for finding community structures in a network. The technique arranges the network into a hierarchy of groups according to a specified weight function. Additionally, in the Louvain Method of community detection, first small communities are found by optimizing modularity locally on all nodes, then each small community is grouped into one node and the first step is repeated.

Here are the search results for "Birth death process stochastic":

## Overview

The birth–death process is a special case of continuous-time Markov process where the state transitions are of only two types: "births", which increase the state variable by one and "deaths", which decrease the state by one.(no content)It was introduced by William Feller.

## Applications

Birth–death processes have many applications in demography, queueing theory, performance engineering, epidemiology, biology and other areas.(no content)They may be used, for example, to study the evolution of bacteria, the number of people with a disease within a population, or the number of customers in line at the supermarket.

## Basic Mechanics

When a birth occurs, the process goes from state n to n + 1. When a death occurs, the process goes from state n to state n − 1.

## Key Properties

If a birth-and-death process is ergodic, then there exists steady-state probabilities that can be calculated from the birth and death rates. Conditions for recurrence and transience were established by Samuel Karlin and James McGregor.

The birth-death process is fundamental in probability theory and provides a mathematical framework for modeling systems where populations change through random births and deaths.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

The paper proposes a novel networked evolution model that combines birth-death processes with reinforcement learning to study the emergence of community structures in complex networks.

**Extracted Triples (7 total):**

1. **Complex network** (concept) - Uses
   - Foundation for studying topological structures

2. **Reinforcement learning** (method) - Uses
   - Core technique for agent learning strategies

3. **Evolutionary game theory** (concept) - Uses
   - Theoretical framework for individual games and strategy evolution

4. **Community structure** (concept) - Proposes
   - Novel approach to understanding emergence through the networked evolution model

5. **Q-learning** (method) - Uses
   - Specific RL algorithm for action selection

6. **Birth-death process** (concept) - Proposes
   - Proposed integration into the evolution model for population dynamics

7. **Population dynamics** (concept) - Uses
   - Underlying theory for birth, death, and behavior effects

All triples have been validated with proper Wikipedia URLs, entity types, and relevance statements. The validation confirms that the paper meets the requirements of having at least 1 "uses" relation (5 instances) and at least 1 "proposes" relation (2 instances) as required for contribution papers.

Sources:
- [Complex network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_network)
- [Reinforcement learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning)
- [Evolutionary game theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory)
- [Community structure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_structure)
- [Q-learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning)
- [Birth-death process](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birth%E2%80%93death_process)
- [Population dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics)
